metadata.title: Synthesis, properties, and applications of black titanium dioxide nanomaterials

sections.text:
from water and to remove organic pollutants from the environment, and titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanomaterials have been treated as the primary photocatalyst for these purposes. However, their large
band gap has largely limited the activity to the UV region of the solar spectrum. The discovery of black
TiO2 in 2011 has triggered world-wide research interests with new hope to overcome this problem.
This review briefly summarizes the recent progresses of black TiO2 nanomaterials, including their synthesis, properties and applications, to provide a timely update and to inspire more ideas in the
related research.
Keywords: TiO2, Black TiO2, Hydrogenation, Nanomaterials, Photocatalysis

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Widely studied over the past decades for many applications, titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanomaterials,
a white pigment and UV absorber in sunscreens, are one of the important photocatalysts for hydrogen
generation and environmental pollution removal as well as photoelectrochemical sensors.[1-14] Among
the commonly seen in four crystal phases: tetragonal anatase, tetragonal rutile, orthorhombic brookite,
and monoclinic TiO2 (B) [6, 15, 16], rutile and anatase phases have been more widely studied due to their higher photoactivities.[17, 18] However, both have a wide band gap of 3.2 eV (387 nm) and 3.0
eV (413 nm), absorbing only the UV light (less than 5% of the full solar energy).[19, 20] In addition,
photogenerated electro-hole pairs can rapidly recombine in TiO2 and lead to a low quantum efficiency.[17] Therefore, it has become important to improve the optical absorption and charge
separation in order to enhance the photocatalytic activity.
So far, many approaches have been attempted.[21-25] For example, introducing metal (such as Fe,
Co, Cr, Ni, and Mo)[26-37], noble-metal (such as Au, Ag, and Pt)[38, 39] or non-metal elements (such
as N, C, F, and S),[22, 40-50], and co-doping metal and non-metal elements (such as Mo+C, Fe+N,
Mo+S, and Co+N, S)[51-57] have been used to enhance the light absorption properties. Huang and
co-workers [43,50] studied the electronic band structures of those doped TiO2 nanomaterials by density functional theory, and explained the mechanism of the enhanced visible-light absorption. In addition,
coupling with small-gap semiconductors (such as CdS and ZnO) or graphene have also been tried.[58-69] Oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ can also been shown with visible-light activity.[68, 70-83]
Feng and Huang’s group [71,73,78-83] prepared several Ti3+ self-doped TiO2 nanomaterials with enhanced photocatalytic activities in hydrogen generation and wastewater degradation. Other factors,
such as phase, morphology, structure, and porosity, are also important for the photocatalytic
activities.[84-86]
In 2011, black TiO2 was reported by Chen et al. [87] using hydrogenation, featured with an optical
absorption onset extended to infrared region (~1,150 nm). Hydrogenation dramatically changed the
structural, chemical, electronic and optical properties of TiO2 nanoparticles. For example, after hydrogenation, crystalline/disordered core/shell nanoparticles are obtained, with a long-wavelength
absorption, structural and chemical defects, and an enhanced electrical conductivity. These largely
changed properties have triggered world-wide research interest in the black TiO2 nanomaterials. This review briefly summarizes the synthesis, properties and applications of black TiO2 nanomaterials, with the hope to stimulate new ideas and more discoveries.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis
sections.text:
2.1. Hydrogenation
Here, hydrogenation means the treatment under an environment containing hydrogen or hydrogen
plasma for some time at certain temperatures.[88] Hydrogenation is a simple and straightforward method. It has been used introduce Ti3+ or other reduction states, and other physical/chemical
properties changes. Interaction between hydrogen and TiO2 was investigated a long time ago.[89-97] In 1951, rutile reduced by hydrogen exhibited a long wavelength absorption,[89] and in 1958, an
increased electrical conductivity was found due to electrons trapped in oxygen vacancies,[92] and the
oxygen vacancy defect states introduced pale blue or dark blue color.[97]
The recent hydrogenation at a high pressure for an extended time (20.0 bar H2, 200 °C, 5 d; 1
bar=0.1 MPa) gave the birth of black TiO2 nanoparticles.[87] Pure TiO2 nanocrystals were first
obtained from precursors of titanium isopropoxide, pluronic F127, hydrochloric acid, deionized water
and ethanol, followed by annealing.[87] The pictures of white and black TiO2 were shown in Fig. 1a,[87] and the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images indicated the highly crystalline nature
of the white TiO2 nanocrystals (Fig. 1b), but the crystalline/disordered core/shell structure of the black TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 1c),[87] where the disordered shell was due to possible hydrogen doping with the formation of the Ti–H and O–H bonds,[87] which was believed to be responsible for the extended
optical absorption (Fig. 1d), and the substantially narrowed gap (1.54 eV) (Fig. 1e).[87]
Fig. 1 (Color online) (a) Pictures of white and black TiO2 nanoparticles. High resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of white (b) and black (c) TiO2 nanoparticles. (d) UV-Vis-near Infrared (NIR) absorption spectra of white and black TiO2 nanoparticles. (e) Schematic illustration of the density of states (DOS) of black and white TiO2 nanoparticles.[87] Reprinted with permission from Ref. [87],
Copyright © 2011 AAAS.
Zhou et al. [98] prepared ordered mesoporous black TiO2 by hydrogenation at 500 °C for 3 h under
normal pressure condition. The pristine TiO2 was obtained via an evaporation-induced self-assembly method combined with an ethylenediamine (EN) encircling process (Fig. 2a). Typically, 1.0 g triblock
the TiO2 nanotubes treated in different atmospheres, inset is the optical images for the different treated samples. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [99], Copyright © 2014 American Chemical Society. (d)
UV-Vis spectra (inset is the partial enlarged drawing) TiO2 and H-TiO2 samples treated at different temperature. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [100], Copyright © 2015 American Chemical
Society.
The color changes of anatase TiO2 nanotubes were compared under different atmospheres: (1) in
air, (2) in Ar or H2/Ar with atmospheric pressure, (3) a high pressure H2 treatment (20 bar, 500 °C for 1 h) (HP-H2); and (4) a high pressure conditions but mild heating (H2, 20 bar, 200 °C for 5 d) [99]. As shown in Fig. 2c, the hydrogenated TiO2 showed much stronger light absorption. Su et al. [100] investigated the effect of temperature on hydrogenated TiO2 which was heated under a gas flow of 10% H2 and 90% N2 for 5 h at 300-600 °C. The hydrogenated TiO2 exhibited a larger absorption with increased hydrogenation temperature (Fig. 2d), and the band gap decreased with the treated
temperature. The remarkable absorption was attributed to electrons trapped below the conduction band
minimum. Wang and Chou [101] compared the hydrogen thermal and plasma treatment on the
formation of black TiO2 nanowire arrays from pristine TiO2 nanowire arrays prepared by a hydrothermal method. Hydrogenation was carried out under Ar (95%)/H2 (5%) atmosphere at 600 °C for 6 h (T-HTiO2) or in Ar (95%)/H2 (5%) plasma for 5 min at 25 °C with the power of 200 W (T-HTiO2). Both hydrogenated TiO2 nanowire arrays exhibited black color and absorption in the visible-light region.
The black TiO2 nanofibers were prepared under mild hydrogen plasma at 300-500 °C for 3 h (Fig.
3a) [102]. The starting TiO2 nanofibers were obtained by electrospining. Typically, Ti(IV) tetraisopropoxide (1.4 g) and 2-propanol (5.0 mg) were mixed with acetic acid (0.318 mg) and
polyvinylpyrrolidone (300 mg), and then annealed at 500 °C to obtain a crystalline phase. The black
TiO2 nanofibers showed a significant absorption in the infrared. The absorption increased with the plasma temperature (Fig. 3b).
Fig. 3 (Color online) (a) Optical difference between pristine TiO2 nanofibers (white) and hydrogen plasma-treated fibers (black). (b) UV-Vis-NIR reflectance spectra of the untreated and H2 plasma-treated TiO2 samples. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [102], Copyright © 2015 American Chemical Society. (c) UV-Vis-NIR reflectance of as-synthesized TiO2 (a-TiO2), H-TiO2 30, and H-TiO2 120. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [103], Copyright © 2016 Nature Publishing Group. (d) UV-Vis absorption spectra of the pristine TiO2 nanotubes (TAN) and hydrogenated black TiO2 nanotubes (TAN-500, TAN-Cr-500, TAN-Cr-350, TAN-350). Reprinted with permission from Ref. [104], Copyright © 2014 Elsevier.
Similarly, An et al. [103] hydrogenated TiO2 with a hydrogen plasma. The time was controlled
within 0-120 min (H-TiO2 30, H-TiO2 120). The starting TiO2 nanoparticles were obtained by a sol-gel
method. All the hydrogenated TiO2 nanoparticles exhibited a high anatase/brookite bicrystallinity and extended the adsorption spectra to the NIR (Fig. 3c). Teng et al. [104] prepared black TiO2 nanotubes with hydrogen plasma in a hot filament chemical vapor deposition apparatus. During the treatment
process, the TiO2 nanotubes were loaded in a corundum boat under the filament. The temperature of the filament was maintained at 2,000 °C, and the samples were treated at 350 and 500 °C (TiO2-350, TiO2-500). The effects of Cr were studied (TiO2-Cr-350, TiO2-Cr-500). All the hydrogenated TiO2 nanotubes possessed a significant absorption in the visible light region (Fig. 3d).
2.2. Chemical reduction

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Aluminum reduction
sections.text:
Inspired by the technique using aluminum (Al) on TiO2 to produce Al-Ti alloy,[105] Wang et al.
[106] prepared black TiO2 nanoparticles using melted Al in an evacuated two-zone vacuum furnace. Their crystalline core-amorphous shell structure (TiO2@TiO2–x) induced a significant enhancement of visible-light and near-infrared absorption. Zhu et al. [107] prepared black brookite TiO2 through Al reduction at different temperatures with oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ states introduced in the distorted
shell, which increased the light absorption and the photocatalytic activity. Cui et al. [108] made black
TiO2 nanotube arrays (B-TNTs) with the melted Al reduction. They first prepared TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNTs) via electrochemical anodization and annealing, and then reduced with Al at 500 °C for 4 h. The
B-TNTs showed a dramatically enhanced light absorption from the visible-light to the near-infrared
region (Fig. 4a). Lin et al. [109] further prepared a series of nonmetal-doped black TiO2. They reduced TiO2 with Al to introduce oxygen vacancies on the amorphous surface layer, and then incorporated nonmetal element X (X=H, N, S, I). All the TiO2-X nanoparticles exhibited an enhanced absorption (Fig. 4b).
Fig. 4 (Color online) (a) Absorption spectra and photographs (inset) of the as-TNTs, TNTs, and B-TNTs. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [108], Copyright © 2014 The Royal Society of Chemistry. (b) Diffuse reflectance spectra of TiO2-X (X=H, N, S, I) and solar spectral irradiance. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [109], Copyright © 2014 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Magnesium reduction
sections.text:
Yu and co-workers [110] reduced TiO2 nanoparticles with magnesium to get black TiO2. Mixed
TiO2 and magnesium powders were heated at 650 °C for 5 h under a 5% H2/Ar atmosphere, followed by washing and drying. A series of reduced black TiO2 were prepared by varying the molar ratio of TiO2 and Mg (BT-X) (Fig. S1 online). Extended absorbance to the infrared region was obtained and increased with the amount of Mg used in the reduction (Fig. 5a).
Fig. 5 (Color onine) (a) Absorption spectra of Mg-treated TiO2 samples. CT: commercially nano TiO2. CT-Ar: the sample annealed under Ar atmosphere. BT-X: X is the molar ratio of Mg with respect to TiO2. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [110], Copyright © 2015 The Royal Society of Chemistry.
(b) UV-Vis absorbance spectra and picture of pristine TiO2 nanoparticles and NaBH4 reduced TiO2 nanoparticles. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [77], Copyright © 2015 Nature Publishing Group.

sections.heading: 2.2.3 NaBH4 reduction
sections.text:
Dark grey TiO2 nanoparticles could be reduced with NaBH4 [77]. The starting TiO2 was prepared
by reacting 5 mL 50 wt% titanium (IV) bis(ammonium lactate) dihydroxide and 60 mL 0.08 g/L
glucose at 170 °C for 8 h, followed by annealing at 500 °C for 3 h. 12 g NaBH4 and 0.5 g TiO2 dispersed in 60 mL water reacted at 180 °C for 16 h to obtain the reduced TiO2 nanoparticles, which showed an absorption edge of 438.2 nm (Fig. 5b). Sun and co-workers [111] prepared black TiO2 with NaBH4. Mixed TiO2 nanoparticle (4.0 g) and NaBH4 (1.5 g) powers reacted at 300-400 °C for 5-60 min.
Adjusting the reaction temperature and time led to a series of TiO2 with colors from light blue to black. A crystalline core/amorphous shell structure was observed with a large visible-light absorption.

sections.heading: 2.2.4 NaH reduction
sections.text:
Brown TiO2 nanoparticles were obtained with NaH solution by Li’s group [112]. A mixture of 5.0
mL dimethylformamide, 100 mg TiO2 (P-25), and 200 mg NaH powder were reacted at 120-150 °C in N2 for several hours (2-4 h). A mercury lamp was used to investigate the impact of UV irradiation on the reaction rate. After treated by NaH, TiO2 changed from white color to brown (Fig. 6a), and exhibited a good visible-light absorption (Fig. 6b).
Fig. 6 (Color online) (a) Photographs of NaH-treated TiO2 (150 °C in N2 for 4 h, UV illumination) and commercial TiO2 (P-25). (b) Reflectance spectra of P-25 and NaH-treated TiO2 sample. A: 150 °C in N2 for 4 h, UV illumination off. B: 120 °C in N2 for 4 h, UV illumination on. C: 150 °C in N2 for 2 h, UV illumination on. D: 150 °C in N2 for 4 h, UV illumination on. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [112]. Copyright © 2016 The Royal Society of Chemistry.
2.3. Chemical oxidation
Xin et al. [113] synthesized black brookite TiO2 by oxidation-based hydrothermal reaction. TiH2
(0.256 g) and H2O (2 mL) were mixed, added with H2O2 (30 mL, 30 wt%), and stirred for 12 h to form a yellowish gel. NaOH (1.0 mol/L) was added to adjust the pH to 9.0. Then NaBH4 (0.4 g) was added and reacted at 180 °C for 24 h. The sample was washed with HCl (1.0 mol/L). The TiO2 color turned to brown after annealing at 300 °C (T300), black at 500 °C (T500), and light grey blue at 700 °C (T700).
The light absorption was enhanced and followed this order: T500 > T300 > T700 (Fig. S2 online).
Similarly, Liu et al. [114] prepared blue TiO2−x nanoparticles. TiH2 powders (0.6 g) were heated in H2O2 at 160 °C for 20-27 h. A strong visible-light absorption was observed. Pei et al. [115] made gray TiO2−x by heating TiO in HCl at 160 °C for 24 h. Stable visible-light absorption was obtained.
2.4. Electrochemical reduction
As illustrated in Fig. 7a, blue TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNTAs) were prepared by electrochemical
anodization and reduction [116]. TNTAs were obtained by anodizing at 60 V for 30 min in ethylene
glycol containing 2 wt% H2O and 0.3 wt% NH4F. After removing the as-grown nanotubes by ultrasonication, a second anodization was performed at 30 V for 1 h followed by calcination at 450 °C
in air for 3 h. Finally, an electrochemical reduction was conducted in 0.5 mol/L Na2SO4 under suitable potentials (between -1.0 and -1.6 V vs. saturated calomel electrode) for 10 min.
Fig. 7 (Color online) (a) Two-step anodization process for the TNTAs preparation and electrochemical reduction process to produce Ti3+ self-doped TNTAs. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [116],
Copyright © 2016 The Royal Society of Chemistry. (b) Schematic diagram for the fabrication process
of blue and black TiO2 nanotube arrays (NTAs). Reprinted with permission from Ref. [117], Copyright © 2016 The Royal Society of Chemistry.
Kim et al. [117] made blue and black TiO2 nanotube arrays as illustrated in Fig. 7b. TiO2 nanotube
arrays were first prepared under 45 V for 5 h in ethylene glycol containing H2O (2.5 wt%)/NH4F (0.2 wt%). Blue TiO2 nanotube arrays were obtained after annealed at 450 °C in air and reduced at a constant current (0.017 A/cm2) for 90 s in a phosphate buffer solution. Black TiO2 nanotube arrays were made with electrochemical proton intercalation and annealing at 450 °C in nitrogen.
2.5. Anodization-annealing
As shown in Fig. 8a, anodization was performed at 60 V for 10 h in ethylene glycol containing
NH4F (0.25 wt%) and H2O (2 vol%) [118]. A second anodization was conducted after stripping off the
nanotubes. After sintering at 450 °C for 1 h in ambient atmosphere and removing the anodic TiO2 layer, black TiO2–x was obtained with a large visible-light absorption (Fig. 8b).
Fig. 8 (Color online) (a) Experimental process and optical images of the stripped TiO2 Layer. (b) UV-Vis absorbance spectra of intact TiO2 and black TiO2–x. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [118], Copyright © 2014 American Chemical Society.
2.6. Ultrasonication
Amorphous black TiO2 could be fabricated via ultrasonic irradiation [119]. The original TiO2 was
prepared through reacting Ti(SO4)2 (12 mL, 8 wt%), ammonia (20 mL, 4 mol/L) at an ice-water bath for 2 h. Ultrasonic treatment (output power density of 1,500 W/100 mL) was conducted at 80 °C for
0.5-8 h. Large visible-light absorption was obtained (Fig. S3 online).
2.7. Laser modification
Fig. 9a shows that the black TiO2 nanospheres were prepared by pulsed-laser irradiation [120]. a
20 mg TiO2 in 1 mL H2O was irradiated by pulsed laser (λ = 355 nm, pulse duration = 8 ns, frequency = 10 Hz, power = 0.35 W, instantaneous power = 4.4 MW) for 5 to 120 min. The color of TiO2 changed to gray after 5 min, and turned black after 120 min (Fig. 9b).
Fig. 9 (Color online) (a) Schematic of the experimental setup. (b) UV-Vis absorbance spectroscopy of TiO2 before and after laser modification suspended TiO2 solution before and after laser modification Inset are raw TiO2, TiO2-5, TiO2-15, TiO2-30, TiO2-60, and TiO2-120. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [120], Copyright © 2015 American Chemical Society.

sections.heading: 3. Properties
sections.text:
3.1. Disordered surface
Chen and co-workers [87, 121] observed a disordered layer near the surface of black TiO2 obtained
through hydrogenation of TiO2 in high-pressure hydrogen atmosphere. Wang et al. [106,122] also revealed the crystalline core-amorphous shell structure in black TiO2 nanoparticles prepared by aluminum reduction, and hydrogen plasma. A nanocrystalline core surrounded by a thin disordered
shell was found in black TiO2 obtained by pulsed laser vaporization method by Tian et al. [123], and a disordered shell of ~2 nm thickness was seen in the hydrogenated TiO2(B)-anatase by Cai et al. [124].
3.2. Ti3+ ions and oxygen vacancies
Ti3+ ions and oxygen vacancies were observed in blacked TiO2 obtained from hydrogenation [102,
125-127], chemical reduction, chemical oxidation, and electrochemical reduction.[116] For example,
Yang et al. [116] found that strong electron spin resonance spectroscopy (ESR) signals at around g = 1.98 and g = 2.00 from Ti3+ and oxygen vacancy, respectively. Su et al. [100] found oxygen vacancy in
the hydrogenated TiO2 nanocrystals increased with the treated temperature (Fig. S4 online). Wang et al. [128] found Ti3+ ions in hydrogenated TiO2 nanosheets from the Ti 2p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) peak, as well as Jiang et al. [129] and Lu et al.[130].
3.3. Ti-H and Ti-OH groups
The surface Ti-H bonds were found in hydrogenated TiO2 nanowires based on XPS study [131],
and so did in black TiO2 by hydrogen plasma [122]. Zhang et al. [132] found Ti-H bonds in hydrogenated TiO2 nanotubes based on the X-ray diffraction peak at approximately 59.28°. The intensity of the OH peak for hydrogenated TiO2 was much lower than pure TiO2 based on their Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra [131]. The OH absorption bands were not observed in
hydrogenated TiO2 nanocrystals, but in pure TiO2 [133]. However, more Ti-OH bonds were observed by in the hydrogenated TiO2 nanosheets [128], and similar OH bands were seen by Chen et al. [134] in their pure and hydrogenated TiO2.
3.4. Valence band edge
The valence band of hydrogenated TiO2 nanoparticles was found with a red shift from 1.26 to -0.92
eV (Fig. S5a online) [87]. A valence band shift from 2.04 to 1.82 eV with a tail up to 1.06 eV was
observed by Yu’s group [110] in their black TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. S5b online). However, similar valence band positions were seen in the pure and hydrogenated TiO2 nanoparticles [127]. Similar observations were reported on hydrogenated TiO2 nanosheets [122].
The above main preparation methods and properties of black TiO2 nanomaterials are summarized
in Table 1.

sections.heading: 4. Applications of black TiO2 nanomaterials
sections.text:
the nanoporous black TiO2 in photocatalytic degradation of phenol, reactive black 5, rhodamine B, and methylene blue [103]. Excellent photocatalytic activity in the degradation of organic molecules in
water was shown by Teng et al. [104] with their black TiO2 prepared by hydrogen plasma assisted chemical vapor deposition. Impressive photocatalytic activities in degradation phenol, human
wastewater, and rhodamine were studied by Yang et al. [116, 140] and Li et al. [148] with their
electrochemically reduced black TiO2 nanotube arrays. Enhanced photoelectrochemical water splitting performance was obtained with black TiO2 nanotube arrays by electrochemical reduced method.[149, 150]
Cai et al. [124] studied the photocatalytic activities of black TiO2(B)-anatase for hydrogen
evolution. The original TiO2(B) were obtained by hydrothermal method [124]. Pt (1 wt%) was loaded on TiO2(B) by wet impregnation method. Hydrogenation was performed under 10 vol% H2/N2 at 400, 575, 650, 750 °C (labeled as H-400, H-575, H-650, and H-750, respectively). As shown in Fig. 10a,
higher photocatalytic activities were obtained with most of hydrogenated TiO2 than the sample treated in pure nitrogen atmosphere at 650 °C (N-650).
the well-balanced Li+/e- diffusion [125]. Mesoporous hydrogenated TiO2 microspheres showed the twice rate capability at 20 C (1 C = 336 mAh/g) due to shorter lithium-ion diffusion path and higher
electronic conductivity [151]. A fast lithium storage performance was also demonstrated in the hydrogenated anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with disordered surface layers and Ti 3+ species [152]. Excellent lithium storage performance with stable capacity retention was reported by Wang et al. [153]
in the hydrogenated, hollow, porous TiO2–x microspheres due to the increased conductivity and the robust hollow structure. A impressive capacity and rate performance was shown in the hydrogenated
rutile TiO2 [136]. At rate 0.1 and 5 C, the discharge capacities maintained at ca. 179.8 and 129.2 mAh/g respectively. The good performance was attributed to the increased the unit cell volume, reduced
particle size, crystalline dislocation, and oxygen vacancies.
4.3. Supercapacitor
An improved performance of supercapacitor was reported in the hydrogenated TiO2 nanotube
arrays, with a large specific capacitance of 3.24 mF/cm2 at a scan rate of 100 mV/s, 40 times higher
than that of white TiO2 nanotubes [130]. A rate capability with 68% areal capacitance was retained when the scan rate increased from 10 to 1,000 mV/s, along with a long-term cycling stability. The
excellent capacitive properties were attributed to enhanced carrier density and increased density of
hydroxyl group. The hydrogenated TiO2 nanotube arrays treated by a hydrogen plasma showed the higher supercapacitor performance [154]. A specific capacitance of 7.22 mF/cm2 at 0.05 mA/cm2 was observed, and 6.37 mF/cm2 at 2 mA/cm2. The impressive performance was attributed to increased
specific surface area, outstanding conductivity and hydrogen passivation of disordered states. The high
capacitive polyaniline/black TiO2 nanotube electrode was prepared by Chen et al. [155] with a capacitance of 999 F/g at the current density of 0.6 A/g for the black TiO2 and a long-term cycling stability, likely benefited from the oxygen vacancies (Ti3+ sites) created during the hydrogenation.
4.4. Fuel cell
The hydrogenated TiO2 nanotube arrays combined with Sn/Pd/Pt ternary catalysts for fuel cells
exhibited excellent electro-catalytic activity and high durability, and a power of 1.21 kW/gPt was
obtained when used as the cathode in fuel cell.[156] The performance and durability of fuel cell was
significantly improved by annealing the TiO2 nanotube arrays in an ultrahigh purity H2 gas at 450 °C for 60 min.[132] The maximum power density reached 500 mW/cm2, and a specific power density of
2.68 kW/gPt was obtained.
4.5. Field emission
Zhu et al. prepared the hydrogenated TiO2 nanotube arrays and the excellent field emission
properties was demonstrated [157]. The turn-on field decreased from 18.23 to 1.75 V/µm after hydrogenation, and a high current density of 4.0 mA/cm2 was reached at 4.50 V/µm, along with a
remarkable field emission stability over 480 min. The good field emission performance was attributed
to increased conductivity and decreased work function. The reduced TiO2 nanotube arrays by NaBH4.also showed the impressive field emission performance [139]. The turn-on field substantially decreased from 18.86 to 1.53 V/µm, and a high current density of 4.0 mA/cm2 was obtained at 4.52
V/µm, with an excellent field emission stability and repeatability. The promising results were attributed
to optimized morphology and introduced oxygen vacancies, which increased field emission sites,
reduced effective work function and increased conductivity.
4.6. Microwave absorption
Excellent microwave absorption performance was found in the hydrogenated TiO2 nanocrystals
[133, 158, 159]. Much higher ε′ and ε′′ values in the frequency range of 1.0-18.0 GHz was observed for
hydrogenated TiO2 nanocrystals, than those of pure TiO2.[133] The enhanced microwave absorption was due to the innovative collective-movement-of-interfacial dipole mechanism in the
crystalline/disordered and anatase/rutile interfaces. Dong et al. [160] also observed strong microwave
absorption in anodized TiO2, due to the interfacial electric field formed at the boundary of crystalline-amorphous phases. Tian et al. [161] reported the good microwave absorption in
hydrogenated BaTiO3, due to the increased resonance of polar rotations with the incident
electromagnetic field. The mechanism of the strong microwave absorption in black TiO2 nanocrystals was investigated by Li et al. [162]. The enhanced microwave absorption of the black TiO2 nanoparticles was originated from the synergy mechanism between their crystalline-cores and
amorphous-shells, rather than the defects and impurities in amorphous phase.
4.7. Cancer photothermal therapy
Recently, Ren et al. [163] demonstrated that the hydrogenated black TiO2 nanoparticles coated
with polyethylene glycol (PEG) showed the properties of cancer diagnosis and therapy. A 40.8% of
photothermal conversion efficiency was obtained with a low toxicity and a high anticancer effect in
vitro and in vivo. A superior photothermal therapy effect was found in in vivo mouse model using deep
blue Ti8O15 nanoparticles with >98% absorption of near infrared light [164]. Cancer cells were effectively eliminated after 808 nm laser irradiation for 5 min, and a low biotoxicity was observed.

sections.heading: 5. Summary and Perspective
sections.text:
In a summary, black TiO2 nanomaterials have attracted extensive scientific interests since 2011
and have shown promising future for many applications. A series of synthetic methods have been
developed, such as hydrogen thermal treatment, hydrogen plasma, chemical reduction, chemical
oxidation, electrochemical reduction, anodization-annealing, ultrasonication, and laser modification.
The enriched methods have provided the flexibility but also complexity in tuning their sizes,
morphologies, properties, and performances. Structural and chemical modifications can be introduced such as disordered surface, Ti3+ ions, oxygen vacancies, Ti-H and Ti-OH groups, to induce the changes
in surface, electrical, optical, and electronic properties. These property changes enhance the
performances in various applications including lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells, field
emission electrodes, microwave absorbers, and cancer photothermal therapies. Accompanied with the
large advance are many open questions and challenges. Firstly, controlling their properties at this stage
seems to be the art of science, due to the large variation of the experimental designs and details.
Secondly, their photocatalytic activities in the visible and near-infrared light region are still far from
satisfactory. The understanding on what and how to improve those activities seems far behind needed.
Current progress are mainly based a try-and-find-out process. Thirdly, it is a challenge to tackle the
nature of the black TiO2 nanomaterials. Both theoretical and experimental studies at this moment have not yet provided a conclusive guidance. Apparently, more efforts, including experimental and
theoretical studies, are needed to advance this new material towards various practical applications.

metadata.abstractText: Photocatalysis has been regarded as one of best solutions to using the sunlight to produce hydrogen (H2) from water and to remove organic pollutants from the environment, and titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanomaterials have been treated as the primary photocatalyst for these purposes. However, their large band gap has largely limited the activity to the UV region of the solar spectrum. The discovery of black TiO2 in 2011 has triggered world-wide research interests with new hope to overcome this problem.
